body:
Personally I go with the following order of preference.
-5, RO, 4, 6, 3, 8, 7, 1, 2, 9, Solo.
I prefer to group them though.
-Top tier - Empire, Rogue One, New Hope, Return, Revenge. (Revenge could also lead the next tier).
-Middle Tier - Last Jedi, Force Awakens, Menace. 
-Bottom Tier - Clones, Skywalker, Solo.

This list has changed a lot in the last few years. Empire is always top, but Awakens has lost some luster. I HATED The Last Jedi when it came out but have really warmed up to it. 1 and 2 were lower for me but have come up recently because of nostalgia perhaps. When I left the theater for Solo, I told myself I would never watch it again because it made me so mad but with another rewatch I kind of enjoy it. 9 is still the ultimate question mark. My first and second viewing was pretty damn negative but with time and perspective I may enjoy it more.

At this point who knows what is next for the films. I was really excited about all the projects announced but it seems like it is in Limbo a bit.

*Edit, added a word.

At this point who knows what is next for the films. I was really excited about all the projects announced but it seems like it is in Limbo a bit.

author.bio: I'm here to watch anime and bang hot ladies... and I've got erectile dysfunction.
author.bio_html: I'm here to watch anime and bang hot ladies... and I've got erectile dysfunction.

body:
The prequels were ill advised and just really strange in a lot of ways, but at least you could tell there was a passion. It seemed like George Lucas had been building a model train set complete with a whole town and lights and moving little miniature cars since the original trilogy, and wanted to share it with the world. Then everyone went in expecting Star Wars and got George Lucas' model train set. It was weird and uncalled for, but you could tell it wasn't just a cash grab.
   
Disney Wars are probably all serviceable movies (I only saw the first one) but there's just nothing there. There was nothing in it that was distinguishable from any other movie put out around the same time. Characters maybe, but really, how many of the characters are only memorable because they're visually striking? Most of the characters I couldn't give a solitary shit about. They're probably fine, but in ten years they won't matter. I'll bet they're seen in the same light as the Star Wars Christmas special is today. 
 
  The first ones I don't generally rank in any particular order because I saw them when I was younger, and haven't really had time to watch them again to really rank them with any criteria than "I liked more parts of that one". I do know they're all excellent movies, and worthy of the hype. Just excellent all around movies. 

As far as hope for the future goes... It's literally a galaxy brimming with stories waiting to be told. I just don't think Hollywood has got the life left in it to tell those stories. Star Wars may well outlive Hollywood. Maybe in a few years Disney will realize how fucking pantshitting stupid it was to do away with the extended universe. Sure it was convoluted, but they didn't have to do away with it entirely. But they won't, and I don't think we will ever get a movie like any of the original movies ever again. Not even a Star Wars movie, but probably any movie. Hollywood just doesn't have the talent anymore.
body_html:
The prequels were ill advised and just really strange in a lot of ways, but at least you could tell there was a passion. It seemed like George Lucas had been building a model train set complete with a whole town and lights and moving little miniature cars since the original trilogy, and wanted to share it with the world. Then everyone went in expecting Star Wars and got George Lucas' model train set. It was weird and uncalled for, but you could tell it wasn't just a cash grab.

Disney Wars are probably all serviceable movies (I only saw the first one) but there's just nothing there. There was nothing in it that was distinguishable from any other movie put out around the same time. Characters maybe, but really, how many of the characters are only memorable because they're visually striking? Most of the characters I couldn't give a solitary shit about. They're probably fine, but in ten years they won't matter. I'll bet they're seen in the same light as the Star Wars Christmas special is today.

The first ones I don't generally rank in any particular order because I saw them when I was younger, and haven't really had time to watch them again to really rank them with any criteria than "I liked more parts of that one". I do know they're all excellent movies, and worthy of the hype. Just excellent all around movies.

As far as hope for the future goes... It's literally a galaxy brimming with stories waiting to be told. I just don't think Hollywood has got the life left in it to tell those stories. Star Wars may well outlive Hollywood. Maybe in a few years Disney will realize how fucking pantshitting stupid it was to do away with the extended universe. Sure it was convoluted, but they didn't have to do away with it entirely. But they won't, and I don't think we will ever get a movie like any of the original movies ever again. Not even a Star Wars movie, but probably any movie. Hollywood just doesn't have the talent anymore.

body:
Top 3

1. Empire
2. A New Hope
3. Return of the Jedi

Bottom 3

1. The Last Jedi
2. Revenge of the Sith
3. Rise of Skywalker

Clone wars isn’t on the bottom list only because people’s motivations kind of sort of made a little sense, even though the movie was cringe and stupid. People act incredibly retarded in the bottom 3 in ways which completely break the movies. They do in most of the non original trilogy, but these three are the worst.
body_html:
Top 3

  1. Empire
  2. A New Hope
  3. Return of the Jedi

Bottom 3

  1. The Last Jedi
  2. Revenge of the Sith
  3. Rise of Skywalker

Clone wars isn’t on the bottom list only because people’s motivations kind of sort of made a little sense, even though the movie was cringe and stupid. People act incredibly retarded in the bottom 3 in ways which completely break the movies. They do in most of the non original trilogy, but these three are the worst.

author.bio:
Goodbye. https://ruqqus.com/+The_Cabal/post/d9y9/i-told-you-so-all-the

Remember: History repeats, and the unaware are doomed to repeat it.
author.bio_html:
Goodbye. https://ruqqus.com/+The_Cabal/post/d9y9/i-told-you-so-all-the

Remember: History repeats, and the unaware are doomed to repeat it.

body:
The OT is the best, especially ROTJ. I actually like the prequels too, especially Episode III (although I think Episode II is pretty boring), I think the main reason people don't is because they have a different setting, it's mostly a backstory. It's definitely different but I don't dislike it.

The sequels had some cool scenes but I feel like they put way too much focus on social justice issues rather than Star Wars. They also changed the characters too much too, ie Luke Skywalker's new personality and beliefs bear absolutely zero resemblance to him in the OT. Finally, it moves way too slow and the special effects in particular take too long, are too realistic, and don't look anything like they did in the other movies.
body_html:
The OT is the best, especially ROTJ. I actually like the prequels too, especially Episode III (although I think Episode II is pretty boring), I think the main reason people don't is because they have a different setting, it's mostly a backstory. It's definitely different but I don't dislike it.

The sequels had some cool scenes but I feel like they put way too much focus on social justice issues rather than Star Wars. They also changed the characters too much too, ie Luke Skywalker's new personality and beliefs bear absolutely zero resemblance to him in the OT. Finally, it moves way too slow and the special effects in particular take too long, are too realistic, and don't look anything like they did in the other movies.

  3. Rise of Skywalker

Clone wars isn’t on the bottom list only because people’s motivations kind of sort of made a little sense, even though the movie was cringe and stupid. People act incredibly retarded in the bottom 3 in ways which completely break the movies. They do in most of the non original trilogy, but these three are the worst.

post.body:
Personally I go with the following order of preference.
-5, RO, 4, 6, 3, 8, 7, 1, 2, 9, Solo.
I prefer to group them though.
-Top tier - Empire, Rogue One, New Hope, Return, Revenge. (Revenge could also lead the next tier).
-Middle Tier - Last Jedi, Force Awakens, Menace. 
-Bottom Tier - Clones, Skywalker, Solo.

This list has changed a lot in the last few years. Empire is always top, but Awakens has lost some luster. I HATED The Last Jedi when it came out but have really warmed up to it. 1 and 2 were lower for me but have come up recently because of nostalgia perhaps. When I left the theater for Solo, I told myself I would never watch it again because it made me so mad but with another rewatch I kind of enjoy it. 9 is still the ultimate question mark. My first and second viewing was pretty damn negative but with time and perspective I may enjoy it more.

At this point who knows what is next for the films. I was really excited about all the projects announced but it seems like it is in Limbo a bit.

*Edit, added a word.

(Revenge could also lead the next tier). -Middle Tier - Last Jedi, Force Awakens, Menace. -Bottom Tier - Clones, Skywalker, Solo.

post.title: Which Star Wars movie is the best? Worst? Hopes for the future?

body:
RLM explains why Revenge of the Sith sucks better than I ever could. The whole movie centers on Anakin’s transformation, which happens for virtually no reason. It’s ham fisted garbage. Palpatine doesn’t seduce Anakin, he just straight up tells him to murder everyone for this vague reassurance that this dream he has won’t happen and he does it.

He speaks and acts like a complete retard, not some tragic love struck fallen hero. I get what George Lucas was going for, it just fails on virtually every level. Even the fight scene, which is the one thing I was looking forward to in that movie, was over the top and absurd. It’s so choreographed and unnatural. It felt way too forced, like some sort of dumb 10 year old’s fan fiction.

And that’s still the best part of the movie.

The whole thing is incredibly bad, I really don’t understand people who think it’s ok, let alone one of the better star wars movies.

TFA was boring, but it set up some potentially cool plot lines. It wasn’t completely nonsensical, although it had stupid parts (attacking starkiller base at the last minute based on some vague assertions from a janitor is retarded, unlike the highly planned and well justified attack based on stolen plans which took a lot of effort for A New Hope). TLJ completely and utterly dropped the ball, but it set up potential for the Disney stuff (snoke could have been cool, expanding on why the resistance was a thing/what the hell was going on in the star wars universe where the first order was able to come back could have bern interesting, explaining what the hell happened with Luke might have been cool, but it was all ruined). It was a hard “meh”, and I had that reaction when it was released (didn’t get wrapped up in the hype train like everyone else at the time).
body_html:
RLM explains why Revenge of the Sith sucks better than I ever could. The whole movie centers on Anakin’s transformation, which happens for virtually no reason. It’s ham fisted garbage. Palpatine doesn’t seduce Anakin, he just straight up tells him to murder everyone for this vague reassurance that this dream he has won’t happen and he does it.

He speaks and acts like a complete retard, not some tragic love struck fallen hero. I get what George Lucas was going for, it just fails on virtually every level. Even the fight scene, which is the one thing I was looking forward to in that movie, was over the top and absurd. It’s so choreographed and unnatural. It felt way too forced, like some sort of dumb 10 year old’s fan fiction.

And that’s still the best part of the movie.

The whole thing is incredibly bad, I really don’t understand people who think it’s ok, let alone one of the better star wars movies.

TFA was boring, but it set up some potentially cool plot lines. It wasn’t completely nonsensical, although it had stupid parts (attacking starkiller base at the last minute based on some vague assertions from a janitor is retarded, unlike the highly planned and well justified attack based on stolen plans which took a lot of effort for A New Hope). TLJ completely and utterly dropped the ball, but it set up potential for the Disney stuff (snoke could have been cool, expanding on why the resistance was a thing/what the hell was going on in the star wars universe where the first order was able to come back could have bern interesting, explaining what the hell happened with Luke might have been cool, but it was all ruined). It was a hard “meh”, and I had that reaction when it was released (didn’t get wrapped up in the hype train like everyone else at the time).

author.bio: I'm here to watch anime and bang hot ladies... and I've got erectile dysfunction.
author.bio_html: I'm here to watch anime and bang hot ladies... and I've got erectile dysfunction.

body: Really though, I just started to think again how DUMB it was to disavow the extended universe. If they just took the time to familiarize themselves with it, they could have told such unbelievably rich stories. They wouldn't have even had to cover most of what happened, the fans will know, and all you have to do is tell a story that jumps off after a point in any one of the major books and you'd get that "Star Wars" sense of mysterious important things happening beyond your view; that the world was alive and you're watching it happen. I don't know why they decided to just make up a less interesting world and throw the awesome one away.
body_html: Really though, I just started to think again how DUMB it was to disavow the extended universe. If they just took the time to familiarize themselves with it, they could have told such unbelievably rich stories. They wouldn't have even had to cover most of what happened, the fans will know, and all you have to do is tell a story that jumps off after a point in any one of the major books and you'd get that "Star Wars" sense of mysterious important things happening beyond your view; that the world was alive and you're watching it happen. I don't know why they decided to just make up a less interesting world and throw the awesome one away.

parent.body:
The prequels were ill advised and just really strange in a lot of ways, but at least you could tell there was a passion. It seemed like George Lucas had been building a model train set complete with a whole town and lights and moving little miniature cars since the original trilogy, and wanted to share it with the world. Then everyone went in expecting Star Wars and got George Lucas' model train set. It was weird and uncalled for, but you could tell it wasn't just a cash grab.
   
Disney Wars are probably all serviceable movies (I only saw the first one) but there's just nothing there. There was nothing in it that was distinguishable from any other movie put out around the same time. Characters maybe, but really, how many of the characters are only memorable because they're visually striking? Most of the characters I couldn't give a solitary shit about. They're probably fine, but in ten years they won't matter. I'll bet they're seen in the same light as the Star Wars Christmas special is today. 
 
  The first ones I don't generally rank in any particular order because I saw them when I was younger, and haven't really had time to watch them again to really rank them with any criteria than "I liked more parts of that one". I do know they're all excellent movies, and worthy of the hype. Just excellent all around movies. 

As far as hope for the future goes... It's literally a galaxy brimming with stories waiting to be told. I just don't think Hollywood has got the life left in it to tell those stories. Star Wars may well outlive Hollywood. Maybe in a few years Disney will realize how fucking pantshitting stupid it was to do away with the extended universe. Sure it was convoluted, but they didn't have to do away with it entirely. But they won't, and I don't think we will ever get a movie like any of the original movies ever again. Not even a Star Wars movie, but probably any movie. Hollywood just doesn't have the talent anymore.

Then everyone went in expecting Star Wars and got George Lucas' model train set. It was weird and uncalled for, but you could tell it wasn't just a cash grab.

Disney Wars are probably all serviceable movies (I only saw the first one) but there's just nothing there. There was nothing in it that was distinguishable from any other movie put out around the same time. Characters maybe, but really, how many of the characters are only memorable because they're visually striking? Most of the characters I couldn't give a solitary shit about. They're probably fine, but in ten years they won't matter. I'll bet they're seen in the same light as the Star Wars Christmas special is today.

The first ones I don't generally rank in any particular order because I saw them when I was younger, and haven't really had time to watch them again to really rank them with any criteria than "I liked more parts of that one". I do know they're all excellent movies, and worthy of the hype. Just excellent all around movies.

As far as hope for the future goes... It's literally a galaxy brimming with stories waiting to be told. I just don't think Hollywood has got the life left in it to tell those stories. Star Wars may well outlive Hollywood. Maybe in a few years Disney will realize how fucking pantshitting stupid it was to do away with the extended universe. Sure it was convoluted, but they didn't have to do away with it entirely. But they won't, and I don't think we will ever get a movie like any of the original movies ever again. Not even a Star Wars movie, but probably any movie. Hollywood just doesn't have the talent anymore.
